stem: A 10-year-old with Sickle Cell Disease is admitted with severe joint pain and a fever of 101.4Â°F. He is crying and reports pain as 10/10. Complete the bowtie to manage this crisis.

actions.text: Apply cold compresses to the painful joints

parameters.text: Pain level and effectiveness of analgesics

rationale.correct: Vaso-occlusive crisis = Sickled cells clogging vessels. Priorities are Hydration (dilute the blood) and Pain Control (usually opioids). Monitoring focus is pain and respiratory status (Acute Chest Syndrome risk).
rationale.incorrect: Cold compresses cause vasoconstriction and WORSEN sickling (use warm compresses). Aspirin is avoided in children due to Reye's syndrome risk. While electrolytes are important, pain and oxygenation/ACS detection are the crisis priorities.
clinicalPearls: Hydration and Oxygenation are the keys to reversing the sickling process.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Oxygen only helps if there is a deficit. Hydration is ALWAYS needed to reduce blood viscosity.

mnemonic.title: VOC
mnemonic.expansion:
V = Vaso
O = occlusive
C = Crisis

Key Actions: Aggressive IV hydration (1.5x maintenance); Around-the-clock opioid analgesics (e.g., Morphine)
Key Monitoring: Pain level and effectiveness of analgesics; Oxygen saturation and respiratory status

reviewUnits.heading: Priority Interventions for Vaso-occlusive Crisis
reviewUnits.body: The priority nursing interventions are: Aggressive IV hydration (1.5x maintenance); Around-the-clock opioid analgesics (e.g., Morphine). Monitor: Pain level and effectiveness of analgesics; Oxygen saturation and respiratory status. Cold compresses cause vasoconstriction and WORSEN sickling (use warm compresses). Aspirin is avoided in children due to Reye's syndrome risk. While electrolytes are important, pain and oxygenation/ACS detection are the crisis priorities.
